<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: To reset the position of the Reader to 0, you can use the mark() and reset() methods of the InputStream class.

Here's an updated version of your code that uses mark() and reset() to reset the position of the Reader:

URL url = new URL("somewebsitecomeshere");
URLConnection c = url.openConnection();
if(getHttpResponseCode(c) == 200) {
    if (isContentValid(c)) {
        InputStream is = c.getInputStream();
        Reader r = new InputStreamReader(is);
        System.out.println(r.toString());

        // Mark the current position
        r.mark(Integer.MAX_VALUE);

        setHTMLString(getStringFromReader(r));
        System.out.println(getHTMLString());
        ParserDelegator parser = new ParserDelegator();
        parser.parse(r, new Parser(url), true);

        // Reset the position to the marked position
        r.reset();

        r.close();
        is.close();
        try {
            Thread.sleep(500);
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    } else {
        log("content is not valid!");
    }
} else {
    System.out.println("ERROR" + c.getContentType() + c.getURL());
}

private String getStringFromReader(Reader reader) throws IOException {
    char[] arr = new char[8*1024];
    StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
    int numChars;
    while ((numChars = reader.read(arr, 0, arr.length)) > 0) {
        buf.append(arr, 0, numChars);
    }

    // Reset the position to the marked position
    reader.reset();

    return buf.toString();
}

<<<explanation>>>: In order to reset the position of the Reader to 0, you need to use the mark() method to mark the current position, and then use the reset() method to reset the position to the marked position. This allows you to read the content of the Reader multiple times without changing its position to EOF.
